data.title: The Canadian Crown
data.data: Canada has many important symbols — objects, events, and people that have special meaning. Together they help explain what it means to be Canadian and express our national identity. We'll learn about important Canadian symbols throughout this chapter. The Canadian Crown The Queen visiting Birmingham in July 2012 as part of her Diamond Jubilee tour. Photo West Midlands Police. The Canadian Crown is not referring to a physical crown, but to the monarchy. Canada has been a constitutional monarchy since 1867 (Confederation), during the reign of Queen Victoria. Queen Elizabeth II was the Queen of Canada from 1952 until her passing in 2022. During her reign, she celebrated her Golden Jubilee (50 years as Queen) in 2002 and her Diamond Jubilee (60 years as Queen) in 2012. The current monarch is King Charles III, who ascended the throne in 2022. The Crown is a symbol of government: Parliament, the legislatures, the courts, police services and the armed forces.1270,1271,1272

questions.question: Since when has Canada been a constitutional monarchy?
questions.feedback: Canada has been a constitutional monarchy since 1867 (Confederation).

questions.question: When did Queen Elizabeth II’s reign as Canada’s queen begin?
questions.feedback: Queen Elizabeth II was the Queen of Canada from 1952 until her passing in 2022.

questions.question: The Crown is a symbol of government: Parliament, the legislatures, the courts, police services and the armed forces.

data.title: Our Flag and The Maple Leaf
data.data: The Canadian flag we use today was raised on February 15, 1965 for the first time. The red-white-red pattern comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston, founded in 1876. Red and white had been colours of France and England since the Middle Ages and the national colours of Canada since 1921. The Union Jack is our official Royal Flag. The Canadian Red Ensign served as the Canadian flag for about 100 years. The provinces and territories also have flags that embody their distinct traditions. The Maple Leaf Canada’s most well known and most respected symbol is the maple leaf. It has been used as a symbol of this country for a long time. In the 1700s, French Canadians used the maple leaf as a symbol. In the 1850s, the maple leaf was used on Canadian uniforms and also put on the headstones of soldiers who died in war.1273,1274,1275

questions.question: When was the flag that we use in Canada today first raised on a flagpole?
questions.feedback: The Canadian flag we use today was first raised on a flagpole on February 15, 1965.

questions.question: Where did the red-white-red pattern of the flag come from?
questions.feedback: The red-white-red pattern comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston, founded in 1876.

questions.question: What is Canada's most well known and most respected symbol?
questions.feedback: Canada's most well known and most respected symbol is the maple leaf.

data.title: Coat of Arms and Motto
data.data: After the First World War, Canada chose an official Coat of Arms. The national motto (expression) is A Mari Usque Ad Mare. This is a Latin expression that means from sea to sea. Coat of arms of Canada. The present design of the arms of Canada was drawn by Cathy Bursey-Sabourin, Fraser Herald at the Canadian Heraldic Authority, office of the Governor General of Canada, and faithfully depicts the arms described in the words of the Royal Proclamation dated November 21, 1921. The present design was approved in 1994. It refers to the large size of Canada from one ocean to another. The arms also contain symbols of England, France, Scotland and Ireland, as well as red maple leaves. You can find this coat of arms on dollar bills, government documents and public buildings. It is also called the Royal Arms of Canada.1276

questions.question: What does the Latin phrase "A Mari Usque Ad Mare" mean?
questions.feedback: The national motto (expression) is A Mari Usque Ad Mare. This is a Latin expression which means from sea to sea.

data.title: The Parliament Buildings
data.data: The people who built the parliament buildings used architecture from French, English and Aboriginal traditions. They also have a Gothic style of architecture which was popular during the time of Queen Victoria. The buildings were completed in the 1860s. In 1916, there was an accidental fire. The Centre Block was rebuilt in 1922. The only part of the building that is still left from the original building is the library. In 1927, the Peace Tower was completed to remember the soldiers who died in World War I. Colline du Parlement, Wellington Street, Ottawa, ON, Canada. There are Books of Remembrance in the Memorial Chamber (room) inside the Peace Tower. All of the names of the soldiers, sailors and airmen who died while serving Canada in war or on duty are written in these books. The provincial legislature buildings have beautiful architecture. The Quebec National Assembly has a French style, and the other legislatures are Baroque, Roman, and neoclassical. Democracy started in Greek and Roman times. These building styles show Western civilizations: Greek and Roman heritage.348

questions.question: What does the Peace Tower help Canadians to remember?
questions.feedback: In 1927, the Peace Tower was completed to remember the soldiers who died in World War I.
options: 1 The soldiers who died in World War I

data.title: The Beaver
data.data: The Hudson’s Bay Company used the beaver as a symbol many centuries ago. In 1834, the beaver became an emblem of a French-speaking patriotic association, the St. Jean Baptiste Society, as well as other groups. This animal is hard-working. It is in the rodent family, which means it is related to rats and mice. It is on the five-cent coin and is on the coats of arms of Saskatchewan and Alberta, and on the coats of arms used by the cities of Montreal and Toronto.349

questions.question: What animal is on the five-cent coin?
questions.feedback: The beaver is on the five-cent coin.

data.title: Sports in Canada
data.data: Hockey is Canada’s national winter sport and Canada’s most popular spectator sport. Ice hockey was developed in the 1800s. Teams in the National Hockey League (NHL) compete to win the Stanley Cup championship. This cup was donated by Lord Stanley, the Governor General, in 1892. Another Governor General, Adrienne Clarkson was the first Governor General of Asian origin. She started the Clarkson Cup, which is given in women’s hockey. Many young Canadians like to play hockey. Canadian children have collected hockey cards for generations. The Montreal Canadiens are a hockey team in the NHL. They won the Stanley Cup in 1978. Canadian football is the second most popular sport in Canada. Curling is a popular ice game introduced by Canada’s Scottish pioneers. The official summer sport is lacrosse. It was first played by Aboriginals. Soccer has the most registered players of any game in Canada355,356,357,358,359,360,361,362

questions.question: Who donated the National Hockey League (NHL) championship Stanley Cup?
questions.feedback: The Stanley Cup was donated by Lord Stanley, the Governor General, in 1892.

questions.question: Adrienne Clarkson was the first Governor General of Asian origin.
What is the second most popular sport in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canadian football is the second most popular sport in Canada.

questions.question: What is the most popular sport in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada's most popular spectator sport is Hockey, which also is the country's national winter sport.

questions.question: What is Canada's national winter sport?
questions.feedback: Hockey is Canada's national winter sport.

questions.question: What is a popular ice game introduced by Canada's Scottish pioneers?
questions.feedback: Curling is a popular ice game introduced by Canada's Scottish pioneers.

questions.question: What is the official summer sport in Canada which was also first played by Aboriginals?
questions.feedback: The official summer sport is lacrosse. It was first played by Aboriginals.

questions.question: Which sport has the most registered players of any game in Canada?
questions.feedback: Soccer has the most registered players of any game in Canada.

data.title: Canada's Official Languages
data.data:
English and French are the two official languages and are important symbols of Canadian identity. English speakers (Anglophones) and French speakers (Francophones) have lived together for over 300 years, sometimes in peace and sometimes in conflict. You must have enough knowledge of either English or French to become a Canadian citizen. Adults who are 55 years or older do not need to be able to speak English or French to become a Canadian citizens. The Official Languages Act was passed by Parliament in 1969. It does three things:
  • Establishes equality between English and French in Parliament, the Government of Canada and institutions which have to obey the Official Languages Act
  • Maintains and develops official minority communities in Canada
  • Promotes equality of English and French in Canadian society
    • 351,352,353,354

questions.question: What are the two official languages of Canada?
questions.feedback: English and French are the two official languages and are important symbols of Canadian identity.

questions.question: When was the Official Languages Act passed by parliament?
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act was passed by Parliament in 1969.

questions.question: The Official Languages Act establishes equality between English and French in Parliament and the Government of Canada
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act was passed by Parliament in 1969. It establishes equality between English and French in Parliament, the Government of Canada, and institutions that have to obey the Official Languages Act.

questions.question: The Official Languages Act promotes the English language in the Canadian society.
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act was passed to promote equality of English and French in Canadian society.

data.title: The Anthems
data.data: The National Anthem O Canada was proclaimed as the National Anthem in 1980. It was first sung in Quebec City in 1880. There are three versions of the National Anthem: English, French and bilingual (part of the anthem is sung in English, part is sung in French). Listen to O Canada here! O Canada! Our home and native land! True patriot love in all of us command With glowing hearts we see thee rise The true North strong and free! From far and wide, O Canada We stand on guard for thee God keep our land glorious and free! O Canada, we stand on guard for thee O Canada, we stand on guard for thee The Royal Anthem The Royal Anthem of Canada, “God Save the King (or Queen)”, can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honour the Sovereign. God save our gracious King Long live our noble King, God save The King: Send him victorious, Happy and glorious, Long to reign over us: God save The King. The Royal Anthem, “God Save the King,” is a traditional song that also acts as the national anthem of the United Kingdom. While the traditional song is English, there is also a French and a bilingual version for official use in Canada.363,364,365

questions.question: Where was O Canada first sung?
questions.feedback: O Canada was proclaimed as the National Anthem in 1980. It was first sung in Quebec City in 1880.

questions.question: How many versions of O Canada are there?
questions.feedback: There are three versions of the National Anthem: English, French and bilingual (part of the anthem is sung in English, part is sung in French).

questions.question: Why would you play the Royal Anthem of Canada?
questions.feedback: The Royal Anthem of Canada, can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honour the Sovereign.

data.title: Honours in Canada
data.data: The Order of Canada Countries like to award citizens who are outstanding. These official awards are honours and are divided in the following groups: orders, decorations, and medals. Canada used to use the British honour system, but now it has its own system. The Order of Canada was started in 1967, one hundred years after Confederation. You can nominate a person who you think deserves honour. The Governor General presents honours and awards on behalf of all Canadians to citizens that Canada wants to honour. Orders recognize significant achievements and remarkable service. The Governor General gave the Order of Canada to Oscar Peterson in 1973. He was a jazz pianist. The Victoria Cross. The Victoria Cross The Canadian honour system has orders, decorations and medals. The Victoria Cross is the highest honour that can be given to a Canadian. It is a Military Valour decoration. This means that it is given for a brave action or self-sacrifice or extremely loyal service to Canada during war. Ninety-six Canadians have received the Victoria Cross since 1854.366,367,368,369,370

questions.question: What are three groups of awards that honour Canadians?
questions.feedback: Awards honour outstanding citizens and are divided in the following groups: orders, decorations, and medals.

questions.question: When was the Order of Canada started?
questions.feedback: The Order of Canada was started in 1967, one hundred years after Confederation.

questions.question: What is the highest honour that Canadians can receive?
questions.feedback: The Victoria Cross is the highest honour that can be given to a Canadian.

questions.question: The Victoria Cross is given for a brave action or self-sacrifice or extremely loyal service to Canada during war.
Ninety-six Canadians have received the Victoria Cross since 1854.
